Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 11:30PM tlm1 wrote: As with all of these things it also depends on the type if imaging used (digital mammography v non digital) plus the ability of the team to understand the results. It was me who started the thread about dense breasts should I be worried? I had been told by one consultant that I had extremely dense breasts - grade 3 to 4 and that I should have an MRI - which I did. Thus had been done by him in his office with an US - not by a clinic with a trained radiologist. I went back to my original place for the MRI - I was due on but the team said it realty did not matter as it would make no difference in how they read the results as their radiologists know what to look for. My consultant who heads up this team is an internationally renowned consultant and surgeon said that for under menopause it should not be an obsessional concern. He is going to give me my density grading at my next mammogram but for my previous one I had both digital mammogram and ultrasound and now MRI. All are fine. Plus he has also clinically checked them. He found a lump not picked up by mammogram or US!!!!!! Figure that - it freaked me out. What I'm trying to say is that I'm glad I am aware of density and how it can affect my risks but I need to put the trust in the team that looks after me, have my regular checks and do things to help lower density. I'm trying not to worry unduly. It does appear that mammogram alone is not great for cancer detection in dense breasts - but is thiswith digital mammogrsphy? If not then definitely request more imaging.
Posts.Title: Dense Breast Tissue Reminder Aug242007 Shar1

Posts.Content: tlm1 wrote: Long story but went for mammogram and ultrasound in December which was all fine. Consultant a very good one (top 5 UK) and gave me all clear. Had some worries so have just been to see another consultant since the other one away. Have just had an ultrasound done by him and he says he thinks I'm fine but I have dense breasts and need an MRI. He says standard practice for him is all three and when I asked him why I was not told this by other consultant he said that probably the mammogram combo meant they felt it was all fine. Now he has also said I'm fine and has only recommended the MRI to start from a base point. However I've looked up dense breasts and there are lots of sites saying its a precursor to cancet etc. How worried should I be? I'm 42and I know it's common to have dense breasts in younger women and it decreases with age and pregnancy. Do you think that something had changed since last tests - surely they would have told me in December? Can density change with menstrual cycle? I'm due on in 2 days. Thanks Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Dense breasts - should I be worried? tlm1 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2012 03:58PM tlm1 wrote: Thanks for all your replies. I'm actually awaiting results of an MRI tomorrow (haf it yesterday) Worried because have been having weird breast issues. I have had tingling and annoying itching and the odd spot that comes and goes plus flushing on one breast. Not swollen or any other symptoms and I'm premenstrual. I had the MRI and asked about the fact I'm due on and they said if makes very little difference and the radiographers have no problem with it. They are also going to do ultrasound and if they need to biopsies. I'm hoping all going to be ok.
Posts.Title: Dense breasts - should I be worried? tlm1 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 09:51AM tlm1 wrote: Hi all Went to get results  - saw consultant radiologist who also did ultrasound and says that my breasts are NORMAL for both MRI and ultrasound! I mentioned re not being able to see IBC on either and she said that that is actually not true, and there was nothing abnormal to see in the first place. I did look up a link that I think is actually really well written www.breastcare.com/common_clinical_inflammatory.htm. It says that whilst MRI can not always distinguish between cancer and the infection, it will highlight areas of abnormality - so whilst it can't always diagnose IBC it can highlight where it might be. In my case they are saying that there is nothing abnormal to see. I also found another interesting article www.springerlink.com/content/47173477t6281465. In this one it says that MRI is th most accurate in diagnosing IBC (bar biopsy). I mentioned my rash which is pale pink and cool to touch, my breasts are not swollen etc and they have said more like a skin reaction.  As the consultant is away I am due to see him in 10 days time when he is back so I figure that if my symptoms have not gone by then I will mention it and ask about a biopsy. He and listed as in the top 25 top breast cancer doctors in the world and the clinic was the first in the UK to introduce digital mammography so I guess they know what they are talking about (I hope!) If he says I'm fine I will believe him. He was able to find a lump last time in my left breast that digital mammography and ultrasound did not - and he predicted that it was benign - which it was. I have taken an anithistamine tablet and the rash is fading which is a relief and I came on today and the breast feel less itchy and annoying. I'm still nervous though and will be for a while longer. In terms of the breast denisty issue the consultant radiologist said that my breasts were not too dense and that it means that you have more milk ducts and glands as opposed to fat. As you get older this should decrease and I'm not to worry about it. Women in their 40's do have dense breasts but of course I will keep an eye on it as I get older.  Any comments  / feedbaack on this would of course be appreciated. Thanks for all your support
Posts.Title: Dense breasts - should I be worried? tlm1 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 08:48AM tlm1 wrote: Update: rash worse with pain so took it upon myself to email the world famous massimo christofanilli. What a lovely man. He emailed back same day despite 5 hour tome delay and asked me to send images. Did that this morning asks he comes back just now - says he can't say for sure as not seen me but given him all the info that he does not think its IBC. He thinks it's more of an infection or autoimmune. I'm in awe that he is so fantastic with this generosity and time- a true medical professional. I feel much more reassured but still need to get to the bottom of this rash. X

I'm due on in a few days which I know can affect visibility but I'm sure he would have told me if he was concerned? I'm know im prone to anxiety and I have to keep telling myself it will be fine. At least this way I will have done the best test possible.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 10:44AM tlm1 wrote: Infobabe - I am lucky to have private insurance via my husband's work. I also happen to live in London so I get a good choice in terms of who I can see. I have to say though I think the US has the 2 of the best best cancer centres in the world - Fox chase and MD anderson. The NHS is great too if you live in the right area of the UK and as long as you have a) a good GP and b) the persistence to get a referral if you need it. My friend works in medecine in a very large London hospital and she has primed me on where the best hospitals are. We now have the right in the UK to demand that an ambulance takes us to a certain hospital providing it does not jeapordise the person's health and it's within a certain distance. For centralish London where we live I know which one is the best for trauma or a head injury, which is best if you have a minor injury and where to take a very sick child.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 04:42PM tlm1 wrote: Ok back again. Things have moved on. Since all clear on MRI and US my rash started getting worse with right breast itchy deep inside. Admit anxiety could be causing both - husband says he wouldn't be surprised if I could grow another head for myself. Anyway went back to other doc who haf originally suggested MRI and he says please don't worry as confident it's nothing. To draw a line under it he agrees to do punch biopsy in an area that's showing rash. The rash BTW is mainly across top of right breast and onto chest and a bit on the top of other breast. Agree could be heat / other reason but I've never had a rash on my breasts before. Now the skin where biopsy taken in red and blanches when I press down. Weirdly the redness covers the area where the rash extended to and takes the shape of it. I also mentioned density of breasts again and said are they dense. Other place says not that dense and common for women my age to have dense breasts. He says they are a grade 3 to 4 (most dense) and also says common at my age. Both his radiographer and other clinics radiographer have looked at the MRI and say all fine. Slight uptake more of dye in right breast but nothing suspicious or any lymph node problems. They looked more or less the same on each side. Finally I suffer from adenomyosis and usually have blood baths for periods. This one is light flow comparably and shorter. Do you think this is all hormonal? Should I be worried. Am I completely stark raving mad? Thanks so much x
Posts.Title: Dense breasts - should I be worried? tlm1 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 06:15PM tlm1 wrote: I have been reading that you can reduce breast density with diet - I had no idea. I eat a fair bit of meat but am starting to see it in a different light. I read somewhere that you should treat meat as a condiment - sparingly. This seems to be sticking in my brain. I've also read that vitamin d can help in lowering breast density. I know my age is a certain factor but if food plays such an important part and if more women's breasts are denser than a generation ago there seems to be an obvious link. Where can I find some articles on this that are reliable and can help in this? One other question - I know alcohol is an important factor in risk for any BC but how important is it for density. I like wine (not in huge amounts but I will often have a glass of red at dinner). Maybe I need to cut this too? Thanks Ps is there a forum for dense breasts on here?
